Engineclub¶

All about Engineclub, home of the ALISS Engine.

Engineclub was started in January 2010 as part of the ALISS project for the National Health Service in Scotland.

See the:

  • Home for ALISS.org
  • Blog for ALISS Project
  • Twitter @ALISSproject
  • Github

There are three groups of applications:

cab¶

  • enginecab
  • home
  • stories
  • youraliss

engine¶

  • accounts
  • analytics
  • ecutils
  • invites
  • issues
  • locations
  • resources

firebox¶

A single application for import of data. This section will be expanded shortly as bulk data import is developed.

API and data model¶

storage of resource data, and services API, using a mix of mongodb and postgresql (for geoDjango location stuff).

  • Engineclub API
    • Authentication
    • Retrieve a resource by id
    • Retrieve resources by search parameters
    • Retrieve resources by batch
    • Submit an item
    • Update an item
    • Submit a moderation
    • Submit an alert for an item
    • Retrieve tags in use
  • Data model
    • Resource
    • RelatedResource
    • Location
    • CalendarEvent
    • CalendarRepeatRule
    • Moderation
    • Curation
    • ItemMetadata
    • Account
    • Membership
    • CollectionMember
    • Collection

Installation instructions¶

Engineclub is a Django project, and uses MongoDB for the main resource data.

You will need a Mongodb database server, installed and running. The Django admin uses a relational database, such as PostgreSQL or MySQL, or you can just use SQLite, which is part of Python from v2.5 and needs no installation or setup. The default settings.py file will default to SQLite.

Currently, installation involves downloading the code from Github, or better is to use Git to create a local repository so you can keep up to date with development:

git clone http://github.com/snowcloud/engineclub.git

The requirements.txt file lists requirements for a working installation. You can use Pip to install these with:

pip install -r requirements.txt

To customise settings, add your own file called settings_local.py. It will be imported at the end of settings.py on system startup.

Following installation, make sure you are in the installation directory, then you can do:

./manage.py syncdb --noinput

This will create the initial database and load an admin user from apps/aliss/fixtures/initial_data.json You can then log in with username: admin and password: admin
